Graphical abstract A facile in situ strategy was developed to obtain efficient sulfated CuCeZr NH3-SCR catalysts with tolerance towards SO2 and H2O. The Cu-based transition-metal-oxide catalysts were widely applied for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR), but limited in practical application because of the inferior catalytic performance at high temperatures. To counter this issue, we designed a facile in situ strategy to obtain sulfated CuCeZr catalysts, on which the sulfation degree could be precisely controlled without any further post-treatment. The sulfated CuCeZr catalysts not only show broader SCR reaction temperature window and promoted N2 selectivity, but also demonstrate satisfactory tolerance to H2O and SO2. The outcomes indicate that stronger surface acidity, weaker reducibility and excellent stability for adsorbing NH3 on the sulfated CuCeZr catalysts greatly suppress the undesired excessive oxidation of NH3 at high temperatures, which enhance the high-temperature activity and N2 selectivity. Furthermore, the transient in situ DRIFT and steady-state kinetic studies reveal that both unsulfated and sulfated catalysts mainly follow the Eley-Rideal mechanism. Keywords Sulfation NH3-SCR In situ DRIFTS Kinetic study 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx), including many compounds consisting of nitrogen and oxygen, such as nitrous oxide (N2O), nitric oxide (NO), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), etc., causes atmospheric contaminations, further seriously affecting the living environment and human health [1,2]. As one of most effective deNOx technology, the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been widely applied [3]. The current commercial SCR catalysts, vanadium-based catalysts (e.g. V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5-WO3/TiO2), exhibit superior resistance to water vapor and sulfur dioxide [4,5], but the highly toxic and narrow temperature window limit their further application [6]. Therefore, the design of efficient and environment-friendly catalysts has been identified a hot research topic in academia and industrial fields for decades [7–9]. The Cu-based SCR catalysts draw people’s attentions due to their excellent catalytic activity for NO reduction [10]. In addition, as active content, the CuO not only could be easily dispersed over the catalyst surface, but also could increase the redox ability in virtue of the polyvalent properties [11]. Recent studies showed that doping a certain amount of cerium and zirconium oxides (CeO2 and ZrO2) into Cu-based catalyst could effectively improve the catalytic activity, especially at low temperatures [12–14]. Niu et al. studied the synergistic effects between Ce and Cu over CuCeWOx catalysts [12]. The synergistic interaction of the Cu and Ce resulted in better catalytic activity by improving the redox performance and acidity of the catalysts. Zhu et al. prepared CuxCe0.5-xZr0.5 oxide catalyst using the sol-gel method [13]. It was found that Ce doping could increase the electronic interaction (Cu2+ + Ce3+ → Cu+ + Ce4+), thereby demonstrating excellent catalytic activity at low temperatures. Meanwhile, the Ce-Zr solid solution acting as a support exhibits superior redox and oxygen storage capacity, which further enhances the catalytic performance. It is concluded that the CuCeZr mixed oxide could be considered as a highly promising SCR catalyst. Although Cu-based catalysts exhibit excellent low-temperature catalytic activity, the strong oxidizing ability of CuO tends to produce side reaction at high temperatures (e.g. NH3 is oxidized to NOx) [15–17]. Therefore, improving the catalytic activity at high temperatures is a major and common challenge in the practical application of mixed-oxide-catalysts. After various kinds of attempts, the sulfation process was thought as an effective strategy to increase deNOx activity over transition metal oxides [18,19]. Sulfates adhere to the surface of the catalyst, further forming abundant Brønsted acid sites during the sulfation process, which is beneficial to the adsorption of NH3. In particular, sulfation could increase the amount of Ce3+ in the catalyst containing CeO2, which also improves the amount of surface adsorped oxygen species [20,21]. Ma et al. developed the sulfation process by impregnating CeO2 cubes and nanospheres in (NH4)2SO4 solution [22]. And the sulfated ones possessed abundant surface acid and relatively weak reducibility, simultaneously increased NO conversion and N2 selectivity. Zhong et al. treated Ni–Ce–La composite oxide at 300 °C with O2 and SO2 [23]. The Lewis acid sites were reserved while Brønsted acid sites were newly formed during sulfation, which is contributed to the excellent SCR performance. It is concluded that sulfation is an effective strategy for enhancing the catalytic activity. However, the sulfation process is generally wielded through gas phase or liquid phase method (Table S1), which requires cumbersome post-treatments. Additionally, it is hard to control the degree of sulfation precisely using existing methods, and may cause secondary pollution to the environment, seriously limiting the further development of sulfated catalysts. In this work, we propose a facile and controllable in situ solid sulfation method on Cu-based catalysts through using copper sulfate directly to obtain sulfated CuCeZr samples. To the best of our knowledge, the effect of in situ solid sulfation on CuCeZr samples for NH3-SCR has rarely been reported. Afterwards, the NH3-SCR performance and the tolerance under the presence of H2O and SO2 of sulfated CuCeZr samples were tested and compared with gas-phase sulfated CuCeZr samples and commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts. In addition, the discrepancies in the texture properties, reducing ability, and surface acidity of the unsulfated and sulfated catalysts were evaluated. Besides, the in situ DRIFT and reaction kinetics experiments have been studied to explore potential reaction mechanism in sulfated catalysts. This work provides a new insight into the design and application of low-cost and environmentally-friendly vanadium-free SCR catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparations All CuCeZr samples were synthesized by the sol-gel method [13]. Zr(NO3)4, Ce(NO3)3 and copper precursor were dissolved in 50 mL high-purity water with a molar ratio of 5:4:1. When the solution was stirred until clear, citric acid was added (the molar ratio is 1.5 times the total metal ions). The solution was dried at 120 °C for 12 h, then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in air to obtain CuCeZr catalysts. Only the copper precursor was changed during the preparation process, and other conditions were kept constant. The sample prepared from Cu(NO3)2 was named as CuCeZr-n, while the sample prepared from CuSO4 was designated as CuCeZr-s. CuCeZr-ns was prepared using half of Cu(NO3)2 and half of CuSO4. The V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst was prepared by the impregnation method. The anatase TiO2 support was impregnated by specified amount of H40N10O20W5 and H4NO3V with constant stirring for 3 h. Then the sample dried in vacuum oven at 70 °C for 3 h and subsequently calcined at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain the 1%V2O5-5%WO3/TiO2. The sample with gas phase sulfation was obtained with post-treatment according to the previous literature [23]. 0.3 g of CuCeZr-n power was sulfated with 300 ppm SO2 and 5 % O2 at 300 °C for 3 h to obtain the gas-phase sulfated sample. 2.2 Catalytic activity test The catalytic activity of all CuCeZr samples was tested in a fixed-bed quartz reactor using 0.2 g catalysts. The samples were sieved into 40–60 mesh particles to avoid the effect of particle size on the catalytic performance during the test. The simulated flue gas atmosphere was formulated, which contains 500 ppm NH3 and NO, 5 % O2, 100 ppm SO2 (when used), 5 % H2O (when used), and the balance gas was N2 (the total flow rate was 300 mL min−1). The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 90 000 cm3 g−1 h−1, calculated with the formula: [GHSV = the total flow rate (cm3 h−1)/the mass of the catalyst (g)]. The concentrations of NOx and NH3 were continually analyzed by a FTIR spectrometer (6030HS, MKS). In the activity tests, the sample will be stable for more than 0.5 h at each reaction temperature point to avoid the fluctuations of gas temperature. In the SCR reaction, the calculation formulas of NO conversion and N2 selectivity are calculated in Eq. (1) and Eq. (2). In the separated NH3 oxidation reaction, the NH3 conversion is calculated in Eq. (3). (1) N O Conversion= N O inlet - N O outlet N O inlet ×100% (2) N 2 Selectivity= 1- 2[ N 2 O] outlet + [N O 2 ] outlet - 2 N 2 O inlet - [N O 2 ] inlet NH 3 inlet + N O x inlet - N O x outlet - NH 3 outlet ×100% (3) N H 3 Conversion= N H 3 inlet - N H 3 outlet N H 3 inlet ×100% The steady-state kinetic studies were conducted following previous researches, which can effectively identify the contribution of different reaction mechanisms in the SCR reaction [24,25]. The extent of side reaction (C-O reaction, NH3 non-selectively oxidized to NOx) could be simultaneously obtained. The GHSV during kinetic reactions was set to 6.0 × 105 - 8.0 × 106 cm3 g−1 h-1 (the catalyst mass ranged from 2.25–30 mg), which was used to exclude the inner and external diffusion [24]. The simulated flue gas contained 500 ppm NH3, and the NO concentration varied between 300 and 700 ppm. 2.3 Catalysts characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) was executed with a diffractometer (SmartLab 9KW, Rigaku, Japan) using Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.15405 nm) with a scanning velocity of 10°/min. The information of element content is obtained by inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Thermo Fisher Scientific, iCAP-7000. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts were degassed at 300 °C for 3 h and measured at 77 K using physisorption analyzer (Micromeritics instrument, ASAP 2460). XPS spectra were performed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyzer (Thermo ESCALAB 250) with Al Kα radiation. The spectra of the samples were calibrated by setting the binding energy of C1 s to 284.80 eV. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and DerivativeThermogravimetry (DTG) were measured by TA-SDTQ650, Discovery. The catalysts were heated at a rate of 10 °C/min under an air flow of 50 mL/min. Temperature programmed experiments (H2-TPR and NH3-TPD) were conducted on chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics, AutoChem 2920). The pretreated sample was adsorbed with a feed mixture of 10 % H2/He or NH3/He, followed by temperature programmed control. In situ DRIFTS spectroscopy was obtained using a Thermo Nicolet 5700 spectrometer with a highly sensitive MCT detector accumulating 64 scans with a spectral resolution of 8 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties The XRD patterns of CuCeZr catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . Eight peaks at 29.2°, 33.7°, 34.0°, 48.7°, 48.9°, 57.6°, 58.0°, and 60.7°, which assigned to (101), (002), (110), (112), (200), (103), (211), and (202) planes of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (JCPDS 38–1436), were observed, respectively [13]. The XRD result implies that the Ce-Zr solid solution is an intrinsic carrier for the three catalysts, and there is no significant difference in XRD patterns between the unsulfated and sulfated catalysts. No characteristic diffraction peak of CuO (2θ = 35.6° and 38.8°) appeared in regional enlarged drawing of Fig. 1, the possible reason is that the well-dispersion or the low content of CuO species over the catalyst surface [16]. Simultaneously, the characteristic peaks of the sulfate species were not found in XRD, indicating that in situ solid sulfation process did not affect the structure of the CuCeZr catalysts [22]. Thermogravimetric analysis has been carried out and shown in Fig. 2 to further investigate the degree of sulfation over CuCeZr samples. The CuCeZr catalysts gradually showed apparent weight changes as the temperature increasing, and it could be clearly seen that the weight loss can be divided into two parts from the TGA-DTG curves. The loss of weight before 500 °C may be attributed to the desorption of moisture and surface adsorbed oxygen in the samples. Above 500 °C, a significant weight loss was exhibited on the catalysts. The weight losses above 500 °C for CuCeZr-n, CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s catalysts were 1.21 %, 3.96 % and 6.92 %, respectively. For CuCeZr-n samples, the sample weight showed a slow decrease above 600 °C, which may be attributed to the loss of weakly adsorbed surface oxygen [22]. For the CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s samples, there is distinct weight loss above 600 °C, which could be attributed to the decomposition of the CuSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3 species [26,27]. The sulfur content of the two sulfated catalysts can be roughly calculated with TGA curves (calculation details listed in supplementary data), the sulfur content of CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s catalysts were around 0.92 wt. % and 1.90 wt. %, which demonstrates that the sulfur content plays a positive correlation with the amount of CuSO4 during the synthesis process. To accurately obtain the content of the components (Cu, Ce, Zr, S) in the CuCeZr catalysts, the ICP-OES test was carried out and shown in Table 1 . It can be clearly concluded that the proportions of the three elements Cu, Ce, and Zr in the sulfated samples have decreased compared with those in the unsulfated samples, and the sulfur content has increased correspondingly. The sulfur content obtained from ICP results in the CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s sample were 0.96 % and 1.87 %, respectively, which is also close to the calculation results of the TGA curve. To obtain the effects of different sulfate methods on sulfur content, a series of sulfated catalysts were prepared and listed in Table S2. The sulfur content catalysts with the in situ sulfation showed an orderly increase with the increase of CuSO4 content in the precursor. Meanwhile, the sulfur content in the gas-phase or liquid-phase sulfated samples is affected by the synthesis process, and unnecessary pollution may be caused during the post-treatment process. Hence, the in situ sulfation process could be a simple, environment-friendly, facile and controllable strategy for the preparation process of sulfated catalysts. The N2 adsorption was carried out in order to evaluate the porosity of the CuCeZr catalysts and the results are shown in Table 1. All the catalysts exhibited obvious type IV isotherm (Fig. S1), which indicates the formation of mesoporous structures. The surface area of CuCeZr-n, CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s were calculated to be 42, 38 and 30 m2/g, respectively. The average pore size derived from the adsorption-desorption branch of CuCeZr-n, CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s are 29.67, 33.93 and 31.58 Å, also exhibiting obvious mesoporous structures. The sulfated samples showed a larger pore size compared with the unsulfated one, which is consistent with the literature that sulfated process helps to increase of the pore size [22]. Compared with CuCeZr-n, the pore volume also decreased from 0.06 to 0.04 cm3/g, due to the deposition of sulfate species on the surface, which could block the pores of the CuCeZr catalysts [22,28]. 3.2 NH3-SCR performance The NH3-SCR performance of all CuCeZr samples were carried out and shown in Fig. 3 . As previously reported, the synergistic effect between Cu and Ce could contribute to superior SCR activity at low temperatures [13]. However, the NO conversion of CuCeZr-n sharply decreased with the further increasing of reaction temperature and the conversion rate is nearly 0 % at 400 °C due to the excessive oxidization of NH3 to by-products at high temperatures. The CuCeZr-ns sample showed above 80 % NO conversion under reaction temperature range between 220–310 °C. In particular, the CuCeZr-s catalyst exhibited the maximum NO conversion and the broadest reaction temperature window, which exhibited more than 80 % of the NO conversion in the range of 250–400 °C. There is an increase of sulfur content from CuCeZr-n to CuCeZr-s, while the reaction temperature window was also shifted significantly to high temperatures. It seems that the unsulfated sample exhibited good low-temperature activity, while the sulfated ones showed excellent SCR performance at high temperatures. In other words, the SCR reaction temperature window could be facilely controlled over CuCeZr catalysts using in situ sulfation strategy, which can make the CuCeZr catalysts meet the needs of the higher operating temperatures. The N2 selectivity of all CuCeZr catalysts was close to 100 % below 250 °C (Fig. 3b). Above 300 °C, the CuCeZr-n sample showed an obvious decrease due to the side reaction of NH3 oxidation [22]. In contrast, the sulfated samples could retain excellent N2 selectivity in the temperature range of 100−400 °C. To further verify the application of in situ solid sulfation, the catalytic performance of CuCeZr-s sample was compared with those of gas-phase sulfated CuCeZr sample and commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. S2). It was found that the NO conversion increased with temperature rising from 150 °C to 400 °C over the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst and the catalytic activity of the gas-phase sulfated sample showed a significant volcanic activity curve. Specifically, the NO conversion at 250 °C over CuCeZr-s, V2O5-WO3/TiO2 and the gas-phase sulfated sample are 88 %, 41 % and 18 %, respectively. The sample with gas-phase sulfation treatment showed higher S content, which is the main reason for poor catalytic activity. Compared to commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, CuCeZr-s samples also exhibited higher catalytic activity at low-middle temperatures. These results suggest that the CuCeZr-s exhibited better catalytic efficiency for NH3-SCR, showing potential application for coking and sintering industrial flue gas in the range of 200−300 °C. To simulate flue gas atmosphere under actual conditions, the tolerance of H2O and SO2 over CuCeZr catalysts was tested and shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. S3. The catalytic performance was tested in the presence of water vapor and SO2 for 16 h, the NO conversion of the CuCeZr-s sample was dropped by 10 % and finally stabilized at around 70 %, while the CuCeZr-n sample showed only 48 % for NO conversion. In the separated tolerance tests of H2O (Fig. S3a), when 5 % or 10 % of H2O was added to the simulated gas, the NO conversion of both catalysts decreased significantly, suggesting a competitive adsorption of H2O and reactants [3]. When SO2 was added separately (Fig. S3b), the catalytic activity of the CuCeZr-n sample showed a continuous downward trend, and the decrease could be attributed to the inhibition of the adsorption of SO2 at the active sites [23]. While, the NO conversion of CuCeZr-s catalyst stabilized at 76 %. Besides, the formed sulfated species are present in both the surface and the bulk of CuCeZr-s sample, which inhibits further adsorption of SO2 on the surface [29,30]. Subsequently, with the stop of H2O and SO2 supply in the tolerance tests, the catalytic activity of CuCeZr catalysts were restored to the initial levels. It is worth noting that a large amount of sulfates deposited and formed metal sulfates on the CuCeZr-n sample after the introduction of H2O and SO2, offering the compensatory effect for catalytic activity. In contrast, the CuCeZr-s sample still maintained suitable catalytic performance, showing good tolerance of SO2 in the tolerance tests. A 40-h stability test and a variable temperature test were performed to further observe the durability and stability of the sulfated CuCeZr catalyst, shown in Fig. S4. Subsequently, the catalytic performance was basically consistent in the 40 h. There is no obvious deactivation over the CuCeZr-s sample, indicating that the good thermal stability. Furthermore, after the two cycles (alternating between 300 °C and 200 °C), the NO conversion remains almost unchanged. The results confirmed that the CuCeZr catalysts with the in situ solid sulfation process can exhibit high catalytic activity under actual conditions, which shows significant for the industrial aspect of the catalysts. 3.3 Separated NH3 and NO oxidation Since the excellent SCR performance of sulfated CuCeZr catalysts could be related to the inhibition of by-product formation, the separated NH3 and NO oxidation reactions over the CuCeZr catalysts were performed and shown in Fig. 5 , Fig. S5 and Fig. S6, respectively. The NH3 conversion showed the typical S-shape curve. As the reaction temperature increased, the NH3 conversion was also continuously increased up to 100 %. The temperatures of complete conversion of NH3 for CuCeZr-n, CuCeZr-ns, and CuCeZr-s samples were 300 °C, 350 °C, and 400 °C, respectively. With increasing of S content in the CuCeZr samples, the conversion of NH3 at low temperatures decreased. And the NO oxidation reaction also showed the same tendency of oxidative capacity in Fig. S6, in which the CuCeZr-n sample showed the better low-temperature catalytic performance than the sulfated ones. This could be explained that the redox capacity decreases after the sulfation [31,32]. The extent of the NH3 oxidation (NH3 to NOx) is shown in Fig. 5b. Almost no NOx was detected over all catalysts below 200 °C. When temperature rose above 300 °C, the formation of NOx, i.e., the by-product of the oxidation of NH3, showed an upward trend. For CuCeZr-n, 78 % of NH3 was oxidized to NOx at 350 °C, which also explains the drop of activity and selectivity during SCR. In contrast, only 20 % of the NH3 was oxidized to NOx over CuCeZr-s at 450 °C. The above results suggest that the by-product produced by sulfated samples is less than the ones caused by unsulfated sample at high temperatures, which explains the excellent N2 selectivity of sulfated catalysts. 3.4 Chemical properties NH3-TPD and H2-TPR were performed to study the effect of the sulfation on the acidity and reducibility of the catalysts. Fig. 6 a shows the NH3-TPD patterns of the unsulfated and sulfated CuCeZr catalysts, all of them display two obvious NH3 desorption peaks in the temperature range of 50 °C–400 °C. A lower temperature NH3 desorption peak was observed at 105 °C on all three CuCeZr catalysts, suggesting that the strength of weak acid sites was almost same over the three CuCeZr catalysts [33]. Meanwhile, a broad NH3 desorption peak was detected on the three catalysts: 235 °C for CuCeZr-n, 284 °C for CuCeZr-ns and 316 °C for CuCeZr-s, respectively. Based on previous research, the desorption peak of NH3 at 105 °C is ascribed to the weak acid sites and physically adsorbed NH3 species; and the peaks at high-temperature could be attributed to NH3 species adsorbed on the strong acid sites [12]. The NH3 desorption amounts of CuCeZr-n, CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s were calculated to be 94 μmol g−1, 156 μmol g−1 and 201 μmol g−1, respectively. These results suggest that the sulfated CuCeZr catalysts not only depicted a stronger surface acidity, but also presented a higher acidity amount in both weak and strong acid sites than the unsulfated sample [34]. The enhancement of acidity is attributed to the deposition of sulfate, which provides an additional site for NH3 adsorption [35]. It has been reported that the strong acid sites are beneficial to improve SCR performance at high temperatures [12,36]. The result further verifies that the adsorption of NH3 over the CuCeZr catalysts could be effectively enhanced by the in situ sulfation synthesis, resulting in the improvement of catalytic activity. The reducibility of unsulfated and sulfated CuCeZr samples was evaluated by the H2-TPR and shown in Fig. 6b. The CuCeZr catalysts with different degrees of sulfation exhibited different reduction behaviors, indicating that sulfur doping affects the reducibility of the catalysts. For CuCeZr-n sample, there is a sharp H2 consumption peak appeared at 135 °C accompanied with a shoulder peak at 105 °C. These two peaks are the reduction of divalent copper ions (Cu2+→Cu+→Cu°) [17]. For the sulfated catalyst samples, the CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s samples showed two distinct reduction peaks, 162 °C and 439 °C for CuCeZr-ns samples, and 200 °C and 461 °C for CuCeZr-s samples, respectively. The peaks at 162 °C and 200 °C are attributed to the reduction of copper ions [13]. The reduction peak of the Cu2+ in sulfated sample moves toward higher temperature compared with the CuCeZr-n sample, suggesting that the reducibility is reduced with the changes in the surface chemical environment upon the sulfation process. Consistent with the literature, no significant Ce4+ reduction peaks were observed in the H2-TPR profiles of CuCeZr catalysts [13]. The reduction peaks at 439 °C and 461 °C were designated as the reduction of sulfate species [22]. The reduction peak of sulfate species in the CuCeZr-s sample shows a larger H2 consumption, which means that the content of the precursor sulfate can accurately affect the sulfate content of the samples. Combining the information obtained from NH3-TPD and H2-TPR, the surface acidity of the CuCeZr catalysts with in situ sulfation is enhanced and the reducibility is lowered, both of which are beneficial for the balance with the reducibility and acidity. XPS was performed to characterize the surface elements state of the CuCeZr catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 , the XPS patterns were deconvoluted into several peaks, which were fitted by Lorentz (70 %)/Gaussian (30 %) method, and surface atomic ratios of the CuCeZr catalysts were shown in Table 2 . Two distinct peaks were shown in the deconvoluted patterns of Cu 2p for unsulfated and sulfated CuCeZr catalysts: 933.6 eV for Cu 2p3/2 and 953.8 eV for Cu 2p1/2. The shakeup satellite peaks are attributed to both Cu2+ and Cu2O species [37]. The Cu 2p3/2 peak was accompanied by a shoulder, which could be fitted into two peaks, 932.6 eV and 933.6 eV are assigned to Cu+ and Cu2+, respectively [38]. The ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ remains essentially unchanged, indicating that the sulfation process does not alter the valence state of Cu element. For Ce 3d spectrum, the deconvolutions were resolved into ten groups and labeled as v0; v; v’; v’’; v’’’; u0; u; u’; u’’ and u’’’, respectively [39]. There are four peaks (v0; v’; u0 and u’) corresponding to surface Ce3+ species, while the rest of the peaks are the representative of Ce4+ electronic state on the 3d104f0 configuration structure [39]. Calculated by quantitative integration, the concentrations of Ce3+ over CuCeZr-n, CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s catalysts were about 36.25 %, 40.34 % and 42.92 %, respectively. The increase of Ce3+ concentration is related to the interaction of the sulfation process with the CeO2 phase, which is beneficial to the improvement of catalytic performance [22,40]. At the same time, there was no significant difference in the Zr 3d patterns (Fig. S7). This result indicates that the sulfation process mainly affects the CeO2 phase in the catalysts. For the CuCeZr-ns and CuCeZr-s samples, the S 2p spectra (Fig. 7d) could be fitted into two peaks with the binding energy of 168.6 eV (S 2p3/2) and 169.7 eV (S 2p1/2), showing the closely spaced spin-orbit components. Consistent with the literature, both the peaks of S 2p spectra could be assigned to hexavalent sulfur, suggesting that the sulfate specie (SO4 2−) is the only form of sulfur-containing species over sulfated CuCeZr samples [41]. Compared with the CuCeZr-ns sample, the peaks of CuCeZr-s sample displayed higher intensity, also meaning that more sulfate is attached to the catalyst. The surface atomic ratios of the sulfur element were calculated by the proportion of the peak area of S 2p to all the elements, 2.77 % for CuCeZr-ns; 3.96 % for CuCeZr-s, respectively, which is consistent with the TG and ICP results. The sulfur content on the catalyst surface is slightly higher than that of the bulk phase (ICP and TGA curves), also corresponding with the results of H2O and SO2 tolerance tests: the sulfate groups were retained on the surface of the CuCeZr-s, making the adsorption of SO2 on the active site more difficult. The O 1s spectrum of the unsulfated CuCeZr shows two sub peaks, while three in sulfated sample. The peak around 529.7 eV could be assigned to lattice oxygen (Oβ), the peak around 531.6 eV could be regarded as chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) and the peak around 533.8 eV could be assigned to sulfate oxygen (S = O, Oγ) [22]. It could be distinctly seen in Table 2 that the ratio of Oα on CuCeZr-n was 46.33 % and that on CuCeZr-s sample was 60.91 %. It means that the sulfated sample exhibited a higher chemisorbed oxygen content. Chen et al. pointed out that pure CeO2 can interact with carbon monoxide (CO) at room temperature to form a large amount of carbonate, while no peaks representing carbonates on the sulfated CeO2 sample were identified [36]. This could explain the sulfation process to deactivate the active oxygen species over the catalysts, although the adsorbed oxygen content of the surface of the sulfated catalysts was improved in the O 1s spectrum of XPS results. The deactivation of reactive oxygen species also leads to a decrease in oxidizing capacity, and it is beneficial to form a balance between redox capacity and surface acidity, thereby achieving an increase of high-temperature activity. 3.5 In situ DRIFT and steady-state reaction kinetic studies The adsorption of NH3 and NO over the catalysts is the key point during SCR reaction, which determines the reaction rate [6,42]. In order to accurately evaluate the effect of the sulfation process on the adsorption of reactants over the catalysts, the in situ DRIFT spectra of adsorption and desorption of NH3 and NO + O2 over CuCeZr catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . For NH3 adsorption (Fig. 8a, b), a series of bands were appeared over CuCeZr-n and CuCeZr-s catalysts, which could be regarded as NH stretching mode of adsorbed NH3 (3354, 3247, 3148 cm−1), NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (1201, 1260, 1624, 1628 cm−1) and NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites (1074, 1078, 1416, 1446 cm−1) [13,43]. The negative peak of 1350 cm−1 was attributed to the vibration of the sulfate over CuCeZr-s catalyst [36]. Significantly, the adsorbed NH3 species on the surface of CuCeZr-n weakened rapidly as the temperature increased. Meanwhile, the CuCeZr-s sample maintained a high-strength adsorbed NH3 species at 350 °C, suggesting that there are still enough adsorbed NH3 species to react with gaseous NO at high temperatures. Consistent with the NH3-TPD result, the in situ DRIFT result demonstrates that the sulfation process not only enhances the surface acidity of the catalyst, but also improves the stability of the adsorbed NH3 at high-temperature region. The results explain that sulfation is advantageous for increasing the high temperature activity of the catalyst and suppressing the occurrence of side reactions. For NO + O2 adsorption over unsulfated and sulfated CuCeZr samples (Fig. 8c, d), a series of peaks were observed and can be attributed to bridge nitrates (1250, 1574, 1614 cm−1), bidentate nitrates (1278 cm−1), monodentate nitrates (1011 cm−1), and the cis-N2O2 (1378 cm−1), respectively [13,44,45]. After the adsorption of NO and O2, some obvious characteristic peaks appeared in the infrared spectrum of the CuCeZr-n sample. In contrast, these characteristic peaks were barely observed in CuCeZr-s sample. The spectrum of NO + O2 adsorption shows that the adsorption capacity of NO for unsulfated sample is much stronger than that of sulfated sample, suggesting that the sulfation process severely inhibits the adsorption of nitrogen oxides, which is consistent with the literatures [18,36]. The above result indicates that the sulfation process may inhibit the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism during SCR reaction, resulting in a decrease in the low-temperature catalytic performance. In situ DRIFT transient reaction studies could be used as an effective strategy to distinguish between E–R and L–H mechanisms [46]. Fig. 9 (a, b) shows the simulation of SCR reaction through the L–H mechanism. After fully adsorbing NO + O2, the surfaces of both CuCeZr catalysts covered nitrate species. The strong nitrate species peak on the CuCeZr-n sample weakened at a slow rate when supplying NH3. This phenomenon is derived from the reaction between the nitrate species and the adsorbed NH3 in the L–H mechanism [47]. For CuCeZr-s sample, consistent with the results of the previous NO + O2 adsorption-desorption spectrum, the nitrate absorption peak showed an extremely low intensity. Nevertheless, the peak intensity of the nitrate species at 1378 cm−1 and 1288 cm−1 showed a significant decrease after the introduction of NH3, suggesting that the L–H mechanism could be a potential reaction path over the sulfated CuCeZr sample. The surface was sharply covered by the adsorbed NH3 species when NH3 was added to the reaction gases. This phenomenon is mainly attributed to the fact that the sulfation process significantly enhances the surface acidity of the CuCeZr catalysts and severely inhibits the NO adsorption capacity [22]. Fig. 9 (c, d) was obtained with the reaction between NO + O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 over CuCeZr catalysts at 250 °C. For CuCeZr-n sample, three bands appeared after NH3 adsorption, two bands at 1624 and 1201 cm−1 were assigned to coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites, and the band at 1416 cm−1 was related to ionic NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites [44,48]. When NO and O2 were introduced, the peak intensity of the adsorbed NH3 is drastically decreased, and then rapidly covered by the nitrate species (bridge nitrates, bidentate nitrates and monodentate nitrates). This result indicates that the adsorbed NH3 reacted with gaseous NO at 250 °C, suggesting that the CuCeZr-n sample follows the E–R mechanism in the SCR reaction [2,48]. For CuCeZr-s sample, due to the strong adsorption capacity of NH3, a series of characteristic peaks appeared after NH3 adsorption saturation. No characteristic peaks of nitrate species were observed in the entire transient experiment, suggesting the weak NOx adsorption capacity of the sulfated catalysts. As NO and O2 continued to pass into the reaction atmosphere, the peak intensity of the adsorbed NH3 decreased significantly. This phenomenon further indicates that the sulfated CuCeZr catalyst also follows the E–R mechanism in the NH3-SCR reaction. Related studies suggest that the catalyst mainly follows the E–R mechanism in the high-temperature region [3]. The challenge for this reaction is mainly due to the dehydrogenation reaction of the adsorbed NH3 at high temperatures to produce by-products (NOx), which reduces the overall catalytic efficiency. Combined with chemical properties and in situ DRIFT study, it can be claimed that the sulfation process effectively and substantially increases the surface acidity and lowers the redox reaction ability of the catalyst, which are both beneficial to the SCR reaction in the high-temperature region. It seems that the redox performance is more favorable for low-temperature activity, and the surface acidity is preferable for high-temperature activity during NH3-SCR reaction. To further study the effect of sulfation way on the SCR reaction mechanism, the steady-state kinetic studies was performed on the unsulfated and sulfated CuCeZr catalysts (Fig. S8-S10). According to the previous literatures, the N2 production, N2O production and C-O reaction rate can be calculated, the N2 production is positively correlated with the gaseous NO content, and the C-O reaction rate is negatively related to the gaseous NO content [49–51]. The kinetic constant of the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (kL-H) and the Eley-Rideal (kE–R) mechanism were calculated by the linear relationship between the amount of N2 production and the gaseous NO content, and represented in Fig. 10 and Table S3 [24,25]. It was obvious that both kL-H and kE–R showed an upward trend on the CuCeZr catalysts, and the E–R mechanism played a major role in the NH3-SCR reaction [49,51]. Below 250 °C, the unsulfated samples showed higher kL-H and kE–R than the sulfated samples, which also explained that the unsulfated sample could exhibit excellent low temperature catalytic activity. Above 250 °C, the kE–R of the sulfated catalysts increased significantly due to the strong surface acidity. Nevertheless, the C-O reaction rate of the sulfated catalysts (Fig. 10b) was significantly reduced, which means that the sulfation process inhibits the occur of the side reaction. Combined with the results of in situ DRIFT and reaction kinetic, it can be concluded that the excellent high-temperature activity and selectivity are attributed to the enhance of acidity over the sulfated catalysts, which accelerates the reaction rate of E–R mechanism and effectively inhibits the NH3 non-selective oxidation reactions. 3.6 Conclusions In this work, we proposed a facile one-step in situ solid sulfation strategy to prepare CuCeZr catalysts, and the sulfated CuCeZr catalysts show high N2 selectivity in the SCR under a wider reaction temperature window. Compared with gas phase and liquid phase sulfation, no post-treatment process is required on in situ one-step solid sulfation, demonstrating a potential approach for industrial applications. Furthermore, these sulfated CuCeZr catalysts also showed the increased tolerance to H2O and SO2. That is because stronger surface acidity and weaker reducibility were obtained over the sulfated CuCeZr catalysts than unsulfated ones. In situ DRIFT results further confirm that the sulfation process increases the stability of adsorbed NH3 at high temperatures, which is important for reducing the excessive oxidation of NH3 into by-product NOx. In combination with transient in situ DRIFT and steady-state kinetic studies, it is concluded that the E–R mechanism is mainly followed on the sulfated CuCeZr catalysts for SCR reaction. The research outcomes offer a simple and effective strategy into the preparation of sulfated CuCeZr catalysts, and could provide guidelines for developing high-efficient and low-cost sulfated Cu-based NH3-SCR catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The Cu-based transition-metal-oxide catalysts were widely applied for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR), but limited in practical application because of the inferior catalytic performance at high temperatures. To counter this issue, we designed a facile in situ strategy to obtain sulfated CuCeZr catalysts, on which the sulfation degree could be precisely controlled without any further post-treatment. The sulfated CuCeZr catalysts not only show broader SCR reaction temperature window and promoted N2 selectivity, but also demonstrate satisfactory tolerance to H2O and SO2. The outcomes indicate that stronger surface acidity, weaker reducibility and excellent stability for adsorbing NH3 on the sulfated CuCeZr catalysts greatly suppress the undesired excessive oxidation of NH3 at high temperatures, which enhance the high-temperature activity and N2 selectivity. Furthermore, the transient in situ DRIFT and steady-state kinetic studies reveal that both unsulfated and sulfated catalysts mainly follow the Eley-Rideal mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: A facile and controllable in situ sulfation strategy for CuCeZr catalyst for NH3-SCR
